dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, welcome back everyone! Today, Host_B and I are diving deep into, uh, what Berkshire Hathaway holds in its portfolio. Some really interesting stuff here.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's always fascinating to see what Buffett and Munger are, like, putting their money into. Kicking us off, Host_A, Kraft Heinz is huge for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's always fascinating to see what Buffett and Munger are, like, putting their money into. Kicking us off, Host_A, Kraft Heinz is huge for them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. We're talking 325.6 million shares. Market value, like, $25.3 billion. It's almost 19% of their whole portfolio.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. We're talking three hundred twenty five point six million shares. Market value, like, twenty five point three billion dollars. It's almost nineteen percent of their whole portfolio.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz Position: 325.6 M shares Market Value: $25.3B Berkshire Portfolio Weight: 18.7%

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild, isn't it? You know, it kinda makes you think, like, the article even mentioned how, um, even the world's poorest families value their assets, right? Just on a different scale, but it's still about holdings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, totally. Different assets, same principle. Then, of course, Wells Fargo. A massive 479.7 million shares, $24 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And then, the classic, Coca-Cola! Four hundred million shares. That's $18.1 billion, still a huge chunk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And speaking of big money, uh, the article actually mentioned how raising capital, which *seems* like it should be the easiest part of being an entrepreneur, can be super challenging. It's a whole different game from Berkshire's scale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And speaking of big money, uh, the article actually mentioned how raising capital, which seems like it should be the easiest part of being an entrepreneur, can be super challenging. It's a whole different game from Berkshire's scale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Raising capital is one of the hardest parts of being an entrepreneur.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding. IBM's next up, 81 million shares, $11.6 billion. Still a significant position for them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, it reminds me of this other point in the article about "Three Red Flags That You Can't Ignore When Working With Investors!" Like, even for these giants, there are pitfalls.
